participants: V. Kellam, P. Senth, Archive representatives
key_arguments: Skeptics: Engine quantifies ignorance. Archive: Engine improves decisions.
outcome: Agreement that Engine useful for clear cases; MUP zone limitations acknowledged

key_arguments: Skeptics: Uncertainty propagates uncontrollably. Archive: Trade-off acknowledged.
outcome: Archive modified weighting; problem not fully solved

key_arguments: Skeptics note Senator Orn funding connection. Archive: Funding source doesn't invalidate method.
outcome: Correlation noted in assessment; no accusations made

key_arguments: Skeptics: Absolute numbers matter. Developers: Relative improvement valid.
outcome: Agreement to report both metrics; methodology document updated

participants: P. Senth, Pollus Brent, Kem Vess
key_arguments: Skeptics: 73% claim inflated. Researchers: Partial matches valid.
outcome: Brent acknowledged methodology clarification needed; seasonal caveats added

topic: Seasonal variation in Pattern Book accuracy
key_arguments: Skeptics: Summer accuracy near-chance. Vess: Acknowledged; investigating causes.
outcome: Seasonal caveats added to all Pattern Book predictions

participants: V. Kellam, A. Vessk, M. Rostak
key_arguments: Skeptics: Grammar implies stability; patterns change daily. Researchers: Metaphor aids understanding.
outcome: Recommendation to retire 'grammar' terminology; partially adopted

participants: P. Senth, Lurra Venn, Traders' Guild
key_arguments: Skeptics: Archetypes describe, not predict. Venn: Description has value.
outcome: Venn appreciated nuanced assessment; archetypes acknowledged as vocabulary

participants: V. Kellam, Traders' Guild, Vorn Oster
key_arguments: Oster: Classification enables policy. Guild: Classification constrains agency.
outcome: Mandatory classification proposal defeated; skeptics' assessment cited

key_arguments: Skeptics: Predictions unfalsifiable. Guild: Historical validation compelling.
outcome: No resolution; both sides acknowledge philosophical difficulty

participants: P. Senth, V. Kellam, Cartographer's Guild
key_arguments: Skeptics: Fitting past data doesn't prove future accuracy. Guild: Best available method.
outcome: Philosophical impasse; both positions documented

topic: Prebel Effect vs Keth method compatibility
key_arguments: Skeptics: Both cannot be fully correct. Guild: Working through internal contradictions.
outcome: Guild acknowledges tension; resolution pending

participants: A. Vessk, former Klutch CC researchers
key_arguments: Vessk: Modeling persons fundamentally limited. Crost: Observation problem unavoidable.
outcome: Project terminated; lessons documented in Crost's paper

key_arguments: Observation changes behavior across Simulated Citizens, Pattern Book, Cartography.
outcome: Cross-system pattern documented; published in synthesis document

participants: A. Vessk, P. Senth, former Klutch CC staff
key_arguments: Vessk: Some persons resist modeling. Senth: System assumed goal-directed behavior.
outcome: Case documented as limit of predictive modeling; published in assessment

participants: V. Kellam, former Klutch CC researchers
key_arguments: Kellam: Successful intervention prevents validation. Researchers: Valid concern.
outcome: Paradox acknowledged as fundamental limit of predictive intervention systems

topic: Legacy of Jackson at Klutch CC
key_arguments: Vessk: Some persons should not be modeled. Community: What was lost?
outcome: Ongoing reflection; no formal resolution

participants: V. Kellam, M. Drusk, O. Kellith
key_arguments: Skeptics: Protocol failed in boundary territory. Drusk: Protocol not designed for boundary.
outcome: Drusk accepted critique; Protocol v2.0 developed with tiered system

participants: V. Kellam, M. Drusk, V. Tonner
key_arguments: Tonner: Experience cannot be codified. Drusk: Some aspects can be.
outcome: Protocol v2.0 synthesis: systematic methods plus override authority

topic: Training framework value vs predictive claims
key_arguments: Skeptics acknowledge training value separate from prediction claims.
outcome: Protocol assessed as valuable training framework even with predictive limits

participants: Archon V. Darran, V. Kellam, Twenty-Ten group
key_arguments: Darran: Skeptics confuse difficulty with impossibility. Kellam: We distinguish claims from capabilities.
outcome: Debate continues; both positions articulated clearly

participants: T. Moss, V. Kellam, P. Senth
key_arguments: Moss: Skepticism has become predictable. Kellam: Skepticism is calibrated to evidence.
outcome: Group acknowledged need to lead with contributions; methodology updated

key_arguments: Murch: We argue whether systems work without defining 'work'. Group: Fair point.
outcome: Assessment methodology now includes explicit definitions section

topic: Role of intuition in technical evaluation
key_arguments: Murch: Intuition is undervalued. Kellam: Intuition needs documentation.
outcome: Unknown Unknown Rule cited as example of institutionalized intuition

key_arguments: Moss: Skeptics never fully endorse. Kellam: See Scrap's notebook.
outcome: Notebook entries shared; distinction between partial and full endorsement clarified

key_arguments: Darran: Skeptics miss larger picture. Senth: Details matter.
outcome: Debate continues; fundamental disagreement about scope of evaluation

key_arguments: Murch: Classification changes the classified across multiple systems.
outcome: Performativity identified as cross-cutting theme; documented in synthesis

topic: On the Uses of Doubt synthesis
key_arguments: When skepticism helps vs hinders; technical evaluation as public service.
outcome: Final synthesis document published; methodology formalized

topic: Role of Densmok in technical evaluation
key_arguments: Capital: Densmok offers valuable external perspective. Densmok: We built these systems.
outcome: Some Capital institutions begin consulting Densmok evaluators

key_arguments: Senth: Assessments should be reproducible. Moss: Process should be transparent.
outcome: Methodology document published with explicit checklist
